importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the occurrence of the tropical storm Fengshen approach, prompting evacuations in the Philippines, highlighting ongoing vulnerability to weather events in a climate-warming context.
The date corresponds to Typhoon Ragasa, which previously impacted the northern Philippines, demonstrating a pattern of repeated natural disasters affecting the region.
A magnitude 7.4 earthquake off southern Philippines occurred on this date, triggering additional quakes and tsunami warnings, illustrating the compounding disaster risks in the region.
A magnitude 6.9 earthquake in Cebu province occurred earlier, killing at least 79 people and contributing to the cumulative disaster burden in the Philippines.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The eye of Tropical Storm Fengshen was forecast to pass near Catanduanes on that day, prompting evacuation actions and coastal flooding risks.

keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes have evacuated their homes due to the threat of coastal flooding from Tropical Storm Fengshen.
The storm is expected to bring heavy rainfall and waves up to 1.2 meters, posing a moderate risk of coastal flooding.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, with vulnerable, impoverished populations in disaster-prone areas.
Climate change is increasingly linked to more powerful and frequent storms, according to scientists.
Fengshen arrives amid ongoing recovery from previous disasters, including earthquakes and Typhoon Ragasa, increasing the strain on emergency services.
Evacuation drills in Catanduanes, a historically early-impacted island, are routinely conducted due to its geographical position in the western Pacific cyclone path.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches the Philippine island of Catanduanes, over 9,000 residents have evacuated due to warnings of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters. The storm, with winds up to 80km/h, is expected to pass near the island later on Saturday, reinforcing its status as a historically vulnerable region. This event occurs amid ongoing recovery from previous disasters, including deadly earthquakes in Cebu and the southern coast, and Typhoon Ragasa. Scientists link increasing storm intensity to climate change, underscoring long-term risks to the Philippines' disaster-prone populations.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
